A Funny Story from Kimberly Tripp

Posted by raymondlewallen on August 5, 2005

Heard this funny story from Kimberly L. Tripp today.

So there was a company whose Sql Server kept crashing about twice a
week, sometime between 2 am and 4 am.  Its was very difficult to
figure out what was going on from examining information, but they knew
it was down for about 5 minutes each time.

So finally somebody sat there, in front of the server, all night
long monitoring the server to determine what could possibly be causing
the server to crash.  After the third day of just sitting there
monitoring, they finally figured out what was going on.

In the middle of the night, the cleaning crew would come in. 
They would unplug the server, plug in the vacuum cleaner, vacuum the
floors for a few minutes, and then plug the server back in.

I wonder if they have the server on a battery backup yet?

Ever have anything or heard of anything like this happening to you or somebody you know?

8 Responses to A Funny Story from Kimberly Tripp

  1. Steve Savage says:
    December 15, 2006 at 1:30 pm

    Back when I was a junior network admin, we had a database/file server at work which was using the incorrect cable to its external RAID bank and didn’t lock properly. It worked fine until one day we had an electrician come into the server room for an evaluation of outlets because we requested some extra 20A circuits. Suddenly the entire network went down and I rushed back to the server room. The electrician was gone but I noticed the database server was turned at an angle. A quick look at the cabling showed that while he was sliding our servers around looking at the outlets behind, he had partially dislodged the ultra scsi cable going to the RAID bank. Amazingly the disks were fine and after a restart we got the system back up. I insisted we switch out the cables to prevent such an occurrence in the future.

    Supervising contractors is a must.

  2. Vladimir says:
    September 16, 2005 at 10:21 pm

    I heard the same story, but it was about emergency room, where patients died every monday night ……

  3. BTX says:
    August 5, 2005 at 11:33 pm

    I had this lady on the phone, that got an error on a computer and I told her to reboot the computer, she says “I tried already, and it comes back with the same error”
    me- so let’s try again
    X- how do I reboot the pc?
    me- see the little power button on the computer? just push that
    X-ok
    …pause
    me-what happened?
    X-the screen went blank
    me- and hasn’t come back?
    X-no
    me- ok, push the button again
    X-ok
    …pause
    X-the error came back up again
    me-what?… can’t be…
    …back and forth the same thing about 3 times, then tried “pull the cable behind the computer” with no success

    …pulled my hair for about 30 minutes… figured out she was turning the monitor off/on instead of rebooting the machine =o|

  4. pvanooijen says:

    This happened over here, about 10 years ago, when servers were quite heavy.
    The machine broke every 3 to 4 months. Monitoring the thing showed something similar. The cleaner came in to sweep the floor, lifted the server to sweep underneath and, with a sigh of releif, let go. Dropping the machine a couple of inches…. After 3 to 4 months the machine surrendered..

  8. johnpapa says:
    August 5, 2005 at 6:06 pm

    That IS funny!

    A client of mine asked me to review their server room to see if they needed any upgrades. When I sent someone out to the server room to check it out, my guy reported back to me that the server room was actually a 4×4 closet chocked full of over 50 network connections on a network panel looking very much like a plate of spaghetti exploded. Once he got through that, he found the servers, which were all running hot. Turns out that not only was the room way too smal with no ventilation, but also they turned the air conditioning off in the room at 5pm and then back on at 8am … um …. this was in a very warm climate year round … often making the “server room” hot as heck. I couldn’t believe it! They were trying to save on electricity (a noble gesture), but in the process they kept on buring out servers and other networking equipment.

    So take make matters worse, they plugged in 3 or 4 fans and pointed them at the room. They plugged them into the outlets in the server room and blew the circuits several times, thus taking down the servers (UPS drained, of course).

    Ah, it was fun.
